flags.title: User-Contributed Project
flags.text: This project guide is not managed by MAKE staff.

guide.introduction:
I have jump started many, many vehicles and yet I still get nervous every time I do it since I know if I make a goof it can destroy the vehicle's computers and ignition system. It can even cause an explosion if I goof. I would appreciate someone supervising my work but I would rather have a gadget supervise me than a person since gadgets aren't only smarter than many people but they also keep their mouth shut! The Jump Start Supervisor fulfills these needs and it does more than supervise it also can provide information about both batteries--the battery to be jumped and the battery that will be used to jump it. In addition, it is useful to let you know if the problem is simply a bad connection so you don't have to put yourself through the jump starting process.

Click Here For a video of the Jump Start Supervisor
guide.introduction_rendered:
I have jump started many, many vehicles and yet I still get nervous every time I do it since I know if I make a goof it can destroy the vehicle's computers and ignition system. It can even cause an explosion if I goof. I would appreciate someone supervising my work but I would rather have a gadget supervise me than a person since gadgets aren't only smarter than many people but they also keep their mouth shut! The Jump Start Supervisor fulfills these needs and it does more than supervise it also can provide information about both batteries--the battery to be jumped and the battery that will be used to jump it. In addition, it is useful to let you know if the problem is simply a bad connection so you don't have to put yourself through the jump starting process.

Click Here For a video of the Jump Start Supervisor

Relevant parts
  • LM3914N IC
  • Diode, 1N4003
  • LED, Yellow
  • Green LED
  • LED
  • Resistor
  • Resistor
  • Resistor
  • Resistor
  • Resistor
  • Potentiometer 2K (Panasonic EVN-D8AA03B23 or similar)
  • Printed Circuit Board
  • Machine screws
  • Hookup wire, solid core
  • plastic cable ties
Tools
  • Screwdriver, small, Phillips
  • Side cutters
  • Small Flathead Screwdriver
  • Soldering iron
  • Voltmeter
  • hand-held electric drill
  • longnose pliers

parts.notes: PC board and kit of all parts is available from http://www.magiclandelectronics.com

lines.text: This is the complete schematic for the Jump Start Supervisor (from now on we'll normally just call it the Supervisor). You can download a pdf version by clicking: http://magiclandfarms.com/JumpStart/Sche...
lines.text_raw: This is the complete schematic for the Jump Start Supervisor'' (from now on we'll normally just call it the Supervisor)''.  You can download a pdf version by clicking: http://magiclandfarms.com/JumpStart/Schematic.pdf

lines.text: This is the foil pattern of the printed circuit board. Since it is a single sided board, it is relatively easy to make the board, However, a professionally made board with silk screening is available from http://www.magiclandelectronics.com
lines.text_raw: This is the foil pattern of the printed circuit board.  Since it is a single sided board, it is relatively easy to make the board,  However, a professionally made board with silk screening is available from http://www.magiclandelectronics.com

lines.text: The Component Mounting Guide is meant as a guide to help you install the parts correctly.
lines.text_raw: The Component Mounting Guide is meant as a guide to help you install the parts correctly.

lines.text: All diodes, including Light Emitting Diodes (LEDs), have an anode lead and a cathode lead.  Because of this the circuit won't work right if you install them backwards.
lines.text_raw: All diodes, including Light Emitting Diodes (LEDs), have an anode lead and a cathode lead.  Because of this the circuit won't work right if you install them backwards.

lines.text: The schematic representation of diode's anode lead is an arrow head.  The cathode is the diode's other lead.  In a physical LED the lead with the shorter lead is the cathode lead. In other diodes the cathode lead is next to the band on the diode.
lines.text_raw: The schematic representation of diode's anode lead is an arrow head.  The cathode is the diode's other lead.  In a physical LED the lead with the shorter lead is the cathode lead. In other diodes the cathode lead is next to the band on the diode.

lines.text: IC1, the LM3914 integrated circuit, must be installed so that its notch lines up with the notch on the comonent mounting guide.
lines.text_raw: IC1, the LM3914 integrated circuit, must be installed so that its notch lines up with the notch on the comonent mounting guide.

lines.text: Resistors can be installed any way--they are not polarized.  However, you must put in the corrector resistor in the right spot.  Pay attention to the color banding which is given in the parts list.
lines.text_raw: Resistors can be installed any way--they are not polarized.  However, you must put in the corrector resistor in the right spot.  Pay attention to the color banding which is given in the parts list.

lines.text: More information in installing parts will be given in the next steps.  Also see the video whose link was given in the Introduction.
lines.text_raw: More information in installing parts will be given in the next steps.  Also see the video whose link was given in the Introduction.

lines.text: Notice when installing the diode the cathode lead (the one with the band next to it) is put in the hole that has a square pad.
lines.text_raw: Notice when installing the diode the cathode lead (the one with the band next to it) is put in the hole that has a square pad.

lines.text: Similarly, the cathode lead of the LED (the shorter lead) is also put in the hole with the square pad.
lines.text_raw: Similarly, the cathode lead of the LED (the shorter lead) is also put in the hole with the square pad.

lines.text: Now all the parts are put into the holes indicated by both the component mounting guide and the circuit board's silk-screen.
lines.text_raw: Now all the parts are put into the holes indicated by both the component mounting guide and the circuit board's silk-screen.

lines.text: After putting in the part, the leads are bent so that the part doesn't drop out of the board while soldering.  See the next step.
lines.text_raw: After putting in the part, the leads are bent so that the part doesn't drop out of the board while soldering.  See the next step.

lines.text: In order to keep the parts from slipping down while soldering, I attached with some wires, an old  folded up sock to the top in order to press the parts firmly against the pc board.  The sock also helps keep the board from moving around when soldering.
lines.text_raw: In order to keep the parts from slipping down while soldering, I attached with some wires, an old  folded up sock to the top in order to press the parts firmly against the pc board.  The sock also helps keep the board from moving around when soldering.

lines.text: Connect a 2 foot long red hookup wire to the hole on the board marked "To Red Cable."  Similarly, connect a 2 foot long black wire to the hole marked "To Black Cable."
lines.text_raw: Connect a 2 foot long red hookup wire to the hole on the board marked "To Red Cable."  Similarly, connect a 2 foot long black wire to the hole marked "To Black Cable."

lines.text: Connect these wires to a DC voltage source just above 12V (12.2 to 12.5 is best.)  This can be a variable voltage regulated DC power supply, a fully charged 12V car battery or, as I did, two 6V lantern batteries connected in series.
lines.text_raw: Connect these wires to a DC voltage source just above 12V (12.2 to 12.5 is best.)  This can be a variable voltage regulated DC power supply, a fully charged 12V car battery or, as I did, two 6V lantern batteries connected in series.

lines.text: If you have access to a voltmeter, check the voltage of your DC power source.  If the voltage is in the range between 12.2V and 12.5V fine.  If it is off a bit keep this in mind when during calibration.
lines.text_raw: If you have access to a voltmeter, check the voltage of your DC power source.  If the voltage is in the range between 12.2V and 12.5V fine.  If it is off a bit keep this in mind when during calibration.

lines.text: Assuming the voltage is between 12.2 and 12.5 use a small Phillips screwdriver to adjust the potentiometer R5 (see photo) so the first green LED just goes on.
lines.text_raw: Assuming the voltage is between 12.2 and 12.5 use a small Phillips screwdriver to adjust the potentiometer R5 (see photo) so the first green LED just goes on.

lines.text: If the voltage is between 12 and 12.25 adjust R5 so the second yellow LED just goes on and if the voltage is between 12.5 and  13.2 volts adjust R5 so the second green LEd just barely goes on.  If your voltmeter registers above 13.2 volts adjust R5 so that the third green LED just barely goes on.
lines.text_raw: If the voltage is between 12 and 12.25 adjust R5 so the second yellow LED just goes on and if the voltage is between 12.5 and  13.2 volts adjust R5 so the second green LEd just barely goes on.  If your voltmeter registers above 13.2 volts adjust R5 so that the third green LED just barely goes on.

lines.text: Attach the Supervisor to the cable, roughly 18 inches from one end of the jumper cable.  While I used plastic cable ties, you also can use #22 insulated hookup wire.
lines.text_raw: Attach the Supervisor to the cable, roughly 18 inches from one end of the jumper cable.  While I used plastic cable ties, you also can use #22 insulated hookup wire.

lines.text: If you do use plastic cable ties make sure they are quite narrow or you will find the yellow LEDs get in the way if you use the larger T-1 3/4(5mm) LEDs.  If you use the T-1 (3mm) LEDs you shouldn't have a problem.
lines.text_raw: If you do use plastic cable ties make sure they are quite narrow or you will find the yellow LEDs get in the way if you use the larger T-1 3/4(5mm) LEDs.  If you use the T-1 (3mm) LEDs you shouldn't have a problem.

lines.text: Pull back the hand grip on the alligator clip with the red handle.  Drill a 5/32" hole in the alligator clip for a 3/8" 6-32 machine screw.
lines.text_raw: Pull back the hand grip on the alligator clip with the red handle.  Drill a 5/32" hole in the alligator clip for a 3/8" 6-32 machine screw.

lines.text: Put machine screw through hole.  Put lockwasher on screw and then start a nut on the screw.
lines.text_raw: Put machine screw through hole.  Put lockwasher on screw and then start a nut on the screw.

lines.text: Remove about an inch of insulation from the end of the red wire that comes from the Supervisor.  Pull the wire through the hand grip in preparation for connecting it to the alligator clip.
lines.text_raw: Remove about an inch of insulation from the end of the red wire that comes from the Supervisor.  Pull the wire through the hand grip in preparation for connecting it to the alligator clip.

lines.text: Wrap the end of the wire around the screw between its head and alligator clip and tighten the screw.  Soldering here is optional.
lines.text_raw: Wrap the end of the wire around the screw between its head and alligator clip and tighten the screw.  Soldering here is optional.

lines.text: Pull back the hand grip to cover screw and connection.
lines.text_raw: Pull back the hand grip to cover screw and connection.

lines.text: We will now show one way of using the Supervisor to supervise the jump starting of a Chevy truck using a Good Samaritan's GMC Suburban.  It should be noted that since we didn't have a non-starting vehicle at our disposal, we are fantasizing a bit since the truck starts just fine without jump starting it!
lines.text_raw: We will now show one way of using the Supervisor to supervise the jump starting of a Chevy truck using a Good Samaritan's GMC Suburban.  It should be noted that since we didn't have a non-starting vehicle at our disposal, we are fantasizing a bit since the truck starts just fine without jump starting it!

lines.text: First we connect the black cable's alligator clip to the truck's ground.  Here we chose a bolt.  Make sure the cable doesn't come close to the fan belt.  If you have trouble finding a good ground connect it to the negative terminal of the battery.
lines.text_raw: First we connect the black cable's alligator clip to the truck's ground.  Here we chose a bolt.  Make sure the cable doesn't come close to the fan belt.  If you have trouble finding a good ground connect it to the negative terminal of the battery.

lines.text: Next connect the red cable's alligator clip to the positive terminal of the battery. The Jump Start Supervisor's green RIGHT WAY LED should light. However, if the red LED starts flashing, you connect the cable's backward and you should reverse them. Make sure the red LED doesn't flash before proceeding to the next step!
lines.text_raw: Next connect the red cable's alligator clip to the positive terminal of the battery.  The Jump Start Supervisor's green RIGHT WAY LED should light.  However, if the red LED starts flashing, you connect the cable's backward and you should reverse them.  ''Make sure the red LED doesn't flash before proceeding to the next step!''

lines.text: This close-up of the Supervisor not only shows the green RIGHT WAY LED lit, but the 5 LED bar graph as well.  Notice that two yellow LEDs and one green LED in the bar graph is lit.  This indicates a good battery, which we already knew it was.
lines.text_raw: This close-up of the Supervisor not only shows the green RIGHT WAY LED lit, but the 5 LED bar graph as well.  Notice that two yellow LEDs and one green LED in the bar graph is lit.  This indicates a good battery, which we already knew it was.

lines.text: If no yellow LEDs light the battery is DEAD and the vehicle should start with a jump.  If only yellow LEDs are lit, the battery is weak and the car may start with a jump.
lines.text_raw: If no yellow LEDs light the battery is DEAD and the vehicle should start with a jump.  If only yellow LEDs are lit, the battery is weak and the car may start with a jump.

lines.text: If any of the bar graph's green LEDs are lit, the problem is unlikely the battery itself, although it might be one or both connections to the batteries' terminals.  To quickly check the connections, turn on the headlights and if the LED bar graph indicates significantly lower voltage, then it might be a connection problem.
lines.text_raw: If any of the bar graph's green LEDs are lit, the problem is unlikely the battery itself, although it might be one or both connections to the batteries' terminals.  To quickly check the connections, turn on the headlights and if the LED bar graph indicates significantly lower voltage, then it might be a connection problem.

lines.text: With the headlights on,  try wiggling the connections to the battery.  If the bar graph's LEDs change while you are doing this, there might be a  bad connection.
lines.text_raw: With the headlights on,  try wiggling the connections to the battery.  If the bar graph's LEDs change while you are doing this, there might be a  bad connection.

lines.text: If tools are available, remove the battery cables, clean them, put them back and tighten them. If you don't have tools, try moving the connections around with your hands.  Jump starting a vehicle sometimes works even when the problem is a bad connection as long as you connect the black cable directly to the negative battery terminal.
lines.text_raw: If tools are available, remove the battery cables, clean them, put them back and tighten them. If you don't have tools, try moving the connections around with your hands.  Jump starting a vehicle sometimes works even when the problem is a bad connection as long as you connect the black cable directly to the negative battery terminal.

guide.summary: The Jump Start Supervisor supervises the jump starting of a vehicle.  In addition, it tests the condition of the battery before attempting jump starting and can be used to find problems such as bad connections, bad starter and problems with the alternator
guide.title: Jump Start Supervisor
